Never mind.  Just found out that there have already been better answers.

I do want to share one more experience, though.  I found out that "use 
test method to explain the method" works well with paired programming (I 
guess it is definitely a good thing for XPers), while it is sometimes 
not that easy to look at someone else' test case and try to figure out 
what in the world he/she was trying to do. :)

Shane

-- 
Disclaimer:  I join all the news groups out of my own interest.  All opinions expressed here are my own and not necessarily those of my employer.


Shane Duan wrote:

>They CAN belong to the same package and I think they DO need to belong 
>to the same package so that you have the freedom to test some package 
>level methods.
>
>Say if you have a class package1.package2.Untitled1 and a testcase 
>package1.package2.TestUntitled1.  The source for the first class should 
>be  src\package1\package2\Untitled1.java and the second should be 
>test\package1\package2\TestUntitled1.  Notice how they differ at the 
>root level but same all the way down?
>
>To compile the file, you just need to specify your source path as 
>"-sourcepath src;test".  Most of the IDE these days support multiple 
>source paths (I cannot say ALL just becasue I haven't seen ALL).
>
>Shane
>
>
